results.title: I'm going home = Je rentre a la maison [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Manuel de Oliveira, Paolo Branco, Madragoa Filmes, Gemini Films, France 2 Cinema and Artificial Eye
results.brief_description: In this elegiac feature from Portuguese director Manoel de Oliveira, Michel Piccoli plays Gilbert Valence, a well-respected, and aging, theatre and screen actor. Valence is aggrieved by the sudden death of close family, retreating somewhat, but also drawing enormous pleasure from the responsibility of caring for his grandson. Internalising his grief, Valence comes to terms with the fact that society is changing whilst he remains the same - his agent offers him parts in lucrative but lowbrow dramas, despite Valence’s protestation that he values his craft; similarly Valence is outraged by the suggestion that he may find solace in romance with a young actress. Piccoli puts in a grand performance as Valence, and de Oliveira captures the savouring of everyday pleasures - a fine new pair of shoes or a daily coffee at his favourite cafe. These observations set a gently comic, if slightly melancholic tone, providing a deft and moving rumination on the themes of aging and artistry. Support cast include Catherine Deneuve, as a fellow thespian and John Malkovich, as an American director. This film represented a breakthrough for de Oliveira, who started his career as a silent era - reflected in the use of expression and gesture to convey meaning, rather than dialogue laden exchanges.

results.title: Suzhou River = Su Zhou He [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lou Ye, Philippe Bober, Nai An, Essential Film and Dream Factory
results.brief_description: The Suzhou River is the backdrop to this haunting tale of obsessive love and mystery set in the not so illustrious part of modern day Shanghai. Told through the eyes and words of a freelance videographer, we follow Mardar (Jia Hongsheng) a motor-cycle courier in his mid-twenties who does his pick-ups and deliveries, no questions asked. However, when Mardar finds himself delivering Moudan (Zhou Xun), the 16 year-old daughter of an alcoholic smuggler, to her aunt, he has no idea what is in store for him. A tender loving relationship soon forms between the two only to be put to the test when Mardar is persuaded by his shady associates to kidnap Moudan and hold her to ransom. Moudan, heartbroken and betrayed, makes her escape vowing to Mardar before jumping off the bridge into the murky depths of the Suzhou River, that she will come back as a mermaid to haunt him. Accused of Moudan’s murder, Mardar spends a few years in prison until his release, when grief-stricken and distraught, he sets out to find his beloved Moudan. When he encounters Meimei (Zhou Xun), a nightclub dancer who performs in an aquarium as a mermaid and who bears a striking resemblance to Moudan, Mardar becomes totally obsessed in the belief that Meimei is his lost love, Moudan. Intricate, mesmerising and visually stunning, Lou Ye pays homage to Hitchcock’s “Vertigo” and Wong Kar Wai’s “Chungking Express” in his treatment of this compelling multi award-winning film. Cinematography by Wang Yu and original music by Jorg Lemberg. (Awards: Paris; Fantasporto; Rotterdam; Viennale)

results.title: Kirikou and the sorceress [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michel Ocelot, Jacques Vercruyssen, Paul Thiltges, Didier Brunner, France 3 Cinema, Monipoly Productions, Odec Kid Cartoons and Les Armateurs
results.brief_description: A delightful animated fable, “Kirikou and the sorceress” starts with a child, Kirikou, speaking to his mother from the womb. Once born, Kirikou seeks about healing his village - principally from the curse that an ill-tempered sorceress has placed on the village including drying up the wells and eating up the men-folk. In his bid to confront the sorceress and see the end to his tribe’s woes, Kirikou undertakes a perilous journey meeting an array of colourful beings and jungle creatures. The charm of the narrative is that it presents from a child’s perspective with uncomplicated views on life, unsullied by conjecture and misguided beliefs. The African village where this whimsical tale is set is abundant with colour, humour, culture and magic, with animation inspired by the earth colours and myths of Africa and imbued with a rich palette reminiscent of 19th century French painter Henri Rousseau. Music scored by Senegalese musician Youssou N’dour.

results.title: Alphaville
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Andre Michelin, Pathe Films and Athos Film
results.brief_description: A secret agent, posing as a journalist, from the ‘the world without’, penetrates ‘the world within’ - Alphaville. In his version of a futuristic dystopia, Jean-Luc Godard embraces a tech-noir aesthetic where human beings have become robotic slaves to technology, deprived of individuality and independent thought. In “Alphaville” the hero, played by Eddie Constantine with an embittered edge, evoking the ghost of Philipe Marlowe, has a mission to eliminate an eminent professor, the inventor of Alpha 60, a superior computer that governs society. The professor’s daughter, Natasha, played with an alluringly demure sensuality by Anna Karina, is the detective’s guide and also his love interest as he negotiates the bizarre, totalitarian state. Godard’s narrative is littered with numerous references, in particular, Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” and George Orwell’s “1984”. Godard uses the modernist 1960 Paris aesthetic to great effect, succeeding in presenting the city as a glimmering, ominous prison, where absurd and inhumane policies intermingle. Several memorable sequences include a firing squad - a cultural performance, accompanied by elegant water ballet sequences - that is witnessed by an admiring audience. An unusual addition to the canon of French New Wave cinema. Glorious black and white cinematography by Raoul Coutard. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Dead or alive 2: Birds [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Takashi Miike, Makoto Okada, Yoshihiro Masuda, Excellent Film, Toei Video and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: This film is an unusual sequel to “Dead or Alive”; unusual in that is has the same two lead actors but virtually nothing else in common with the original in terms of plot. In this instalment (one of three) Sho Aikawa plays Mizuki Okamoto, a hit man hired to execute a member of the Yakuza. But instead the opportunity is missed when a mysterious man beats him to it. Fearing retribution Okamoto flees to the small island of his youth, only to be met by the same assassin whom he discovers is an old friend. Together, the two of them join forces using the proceeds from hits to buy vaccines for Third World children. Despite this set-up, Miike has very little use for the conventions of narrative, preferring to engage in the violent, kinetic excesses that are his signature, not to mention the dabbling in surrealist motifs, flashbacks and asides that often baffle. An intriguing mix of humour and action with redemptive overtones. Cast includes Show Aikawa, Riki Takeuchi, Endo Kenichi, Shinya Tsukamoto and Edison Chen.

results.title: The Harder they come [DVD]
results.brief_description: The first independent feature film produced in Jamaica gave many Americans their first taste of reggae music with musician Jimmy Cliff in the title role, backed by a fabulous reggae soundtrack. Cliff plays Ivan, a naive rural singer who moves to the city in search of fame but is soon impoverished and exploited by the music industry before becoming embroiled in the trade of marijuana and murder; simultaneously Ivan’s music is released to great acclaim and he becomes somewhat of a local anti-hero. As well as offering a unique view of the reggae scene the milieu of this film also offers a de-romanticised view of seedy Kingston life. Indeed Henzell’s style borders on documentary, as he evokes the squalor of the street, the impoverishment of the people and the multi-faceted systemic corruption. Soundtrack includes the title track as well as other reggae hits “You Can Really Get It if You Want It”, “Sitting in Limbo” and “Johnny Too Bad”. Cast includes Basil Keane, Ras Daniel Hartman, Winston Stona, Janet Barkley, Bobby Charlton and Carl Bradshaw.

results.title: Intimacy
results.creator_credit: Patrice Chereau, Patrick Cassavetti, Jacques Hinstin, Canal+, Azor Films and Arte France
results.brief_description: The opening moments of “Intimacy” set the scene perfectly for this erotic drama, that is also an examination of an quite ordinary marriage: two people, in a grotty, shambolic London house, engage in urgent and silent sex, communicating nothing other than their instinct for lust and pleasure. As the narrative unfurls we discover segments of both protagonists’ lives, and possible explanations about the motivations that inspire their urges. For Claire, it is perhaps an escape from the ordinariness of her life as a wife, mother and amateur actress; for Jay, it is perhaps an emotional stopgap for the absence of his wife and son. Despite the agreed anonymity of their union, Jay starts to obsess over Claire’s life outside of their ribald encounters and stalks her, discovering her family commitments and even anonymously befriending her husband, Andy. Jay toys with Andy (Timothy Spall) spinning a tale of the married woman and mother of one, that he meets weekly for sex, encouraging Andy to ponder what drives a woman to such deeds. Within this intriguing set-up, lie concealed details about characters’ motivation, leaving the viewer with only a very superficial view of what spurs the protagonists’ conduct. Hence, despite attempts at realism via the aesthetic de-glamorisation of the characters, the narrative is simply aimless eroticism that will be remembered not for its art but for the scandal garnered due to the depiction of actual fellatio and masturbation. Based on a story by Hanif Kureishi and the first English-language film for French director Patrice Chereau. Also stars Mark Rylance (as Jay) and Marianne Faithfull.

results.title: Bowling for Columbine [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Moore, Kathleen Glynn, Jim Czarnecki, VIF 2, Salter Street Films and Dog Eat Dog Films
results.brief_description: Michael Moore’s 2002 documentary came in the wake of the burgeoning fame and infamy that the social and media commentator, agent provocateur, satirist and political activist garnered with his television series, “The Awful truth” and publications including “Stupid white men”. In this work Moore addresses the problem of violence in America, focusing on gun culture, the prevalence of gun ownership and the sanctity of the American right to bear arms. Moore’s approach is to interview a variety of people attempting to depict a tapestry that may explain America’s relationship to guns. Among his interviewees are student survivors of the 1999 Columbine school massacre, National Rifle Association spokesperson and actor, Charlton Heston, politicians, police and various gun enthusiasts. Moore tries to dispel myths that are propagated as an explanation as to why American society is so at war with itself - its bloody history, the volume of guns amid the population, violence in the media, American’s preponderance for violent video games and films. Moore questions these theories by focusing on other less violent countries with these same qualities. One of Moore’s strongest theories is that the scare-mongering prevalent in society, broadcast through the media, and the popularity of reality TV shows, such as “COPS”, promotes the notion that danger is omnipresent to the individual and must be countered. Winner of Best Documentary at the 2003 Academy Awards, Moore’s acceptance speech earned him even greater notoriety when he criticised US President Bush and the war on Iraq.

results.title: Camila [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Maria Luisa Bemberg, Lita Stantic, Impala S.A. (SP) and GEA Cinematografica S R L
results.brief_description: Set in a small Argentinean town in 1847, Camila (played by Susu Pecoraro) is the daughter of a wealthy diplomat growing up amid a bucolic and privileged, albeit confined, existence. Camila grows up to be a headstrong woman who clashes frequently with her conservative family. When she confesses the conflicted thoughts and disturbing dreams that concern her to Ladislao Gutierez (Imanol Arias), a Jesuit priest, the two soon enter into a torrid affair. Defying convention, her tyrannical father and overwhelming opposition from the Church and society, the doomed lovers are driven into exile where they live together anonymously. Despite their passionate union they continue to suffer torment and guilt as a result of their choices. As a political critique, “Camila” lays bare the power that the conservative, repressive Rosas government had over the people of Argentina at that time although the narrative skirts around the complexities of these issues in favour of the lovers’ plight. Based on a true story, which was reputedly suppressed by authorities due to its controversial subject matter, this historical melodrama pays great attention to period detail, serving as a fascinating portrait of Argentinean culture, in particular religious traditions and societal mores. Where it lacks perhaps is in its traditional depiction of the lovers’ passion, manifested in several bodice-ripping sequences. Cast also includes Hector Alterio, Elena Tasisto, Carlos Munoz and Hector Pellegrini. Academy Award nominee for Best Foreign Language Film.

results.title: Swept away = Travolti da un insolito destino nell'azzurro mare d'agosto [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lina Wertmüller, Romano Cardarelli and Medusa Distribuzione
results.brief_description: Lina Wertmuller’s castaway drama is a satire on the class war between the wealthy elite and the proletariats. Raffaella (Mariangela Melato) is the very rich, spoilt and opinionated wife of a wealthy Italian capitalist. On a yachting trip around the Mediterranean Islands she constantly berates him for his politics and personal views whilst also delighting in taunting and criticising a deck hand, Gennarino, whose commitment to Communism and unstinting belief in the cause, fuel his antagonism toward her. When Raffaella insists that Gennarino take her out in a dingy for a swim, the pair becomes stranded from the boat, ending up on a deserted island. Once there, the prescribed social roles are subverted when basic needs of food and shelter become tantamount. Raffaella, helpless in her survival skills, becomes enslaved to the edicts of Gennarino who now relishes in his role as master. Nonetheless romance blossoms and Raffaella and Gennarino become accustomed to their new roles - in fact Raeffaella declares to have found happiness amid this basic existence. Whilst the set-up of Wertmuller’s work is intriguing, drawing on the political frictions of Italian society whilst examining the fundamentals of human nature and desire, the brutality of Gennarino’s attitude to Raeffaella (including physical violence) is troubling, especially in light of her devotion. Interestingly it is Raeffaella who is aware that their love stands little chance of survival in the real world, and Gennarino who remains deluded. Full title translates as “Swept away… by an unusual destiny in the blue sea of August”.
